customer_name: Kern County Superintendent of Schools CALM

citations.narrative:
The emergency action plan addresses animal escapes and human emergencies, but has not been updated to a hazards
based approach, including HVAC fail or electrical outages as required by the Animal Welfare Act. Contingency plans must
identify emergencies such as electrical outages, faulty HVAC systems, fires, mechanical breakdowns and natural
disasters most likely to be experienced by the facility in order to provide for the welfare of the covered animals.
Correct by: 10/04/2024

A number of enclosures had sharp points present:
There were screws and nails pointing into the enclosure containing 2 Red tailed Hawks and the enclosure with a Screech
owl.
There were lose metal bands and sharp screws pointing into an enclosure with 2 Crows and another enclosure with a
Raven.
There was piece of broken metal tape in the Enclosure containing a ferruginous hawk and a Swainson's hawk.
All of the birds were free in each of their enclosures with access to the sharp points. The primary enclosure must be
constructed and maintained so that they have no sharp points that could potentially injure the birds.
Correct by: 09/27/2024

A Red-Trailed Hawk Enclosure had many walls with exposed damaged plywood that was not able to be effectively
cleaned and sanitized. Additionally, the woodpecker enclosure had rusty support beams. Enclosures must be constructed
and maintained so that all surfaces in contact with the birds may be readily cleaned and/or sanitized in accordance with
3.158 or be replaced when worn or soiled.
Correct by: 09/26/2024

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility did not have a documented environment enhancement plan to promote psychological well-being of their avian
species as required by the Animal Welfare Act. The facility must develop, document and follow a species appropriate plan
for environmental enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by
the attending veterinarian, and at a minimum must address social grouping, environmental enrichment, special
considerations, restraint, and exemptions to the plan regulation and be in accordance with currently accepted professional
standards.
Correct by: 09/26/2024

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The primary enclosure with a RedTailed Hawk was dirty with a buildup of wet excrement covering the walls. Insufficient
cleaning can lead to disease hazards, insects, pest and odors. Excreta must be removed from within, under, and around
the primary enclosure often enough to prevent excessive accumulation.
Correct by: 09/26/2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Facility Representative.
n

narrative:
2.134(a)(1) 
   
Contingency planning. 
The emergency action plan addresses animal escapes and human emergencies, but has not been updated to a hazards 
based approach, including HVAC fail or electrical outages as required by the Animal Welfare Act. Contingency plans must 
identify emergencies such as electrical outages, faulty HVAC systems, fires, mechanical breakdowns and natural 
disasters most likely to be experienced by the facility in order to provide for the welfare of the covered animals. 
Correct by: 10/04/2024 
3.153(a)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
A number of enclosures had sharp points present:  
There were screws and nails pointing into the enclosure containing 2 Red tailed Hawks and the enclosure with a Screech 
owl. 
There were lose metal bands and sharp screws pointing into an enclosure with 2 Crows and another enclosure with a 
Raven. 
There was piece of broken metal tape in the Enclosure containing a ferruginous hawk and a Swainson's hawk. 
All of the birds were free in each of their enclosures with access to the sharp points. The primary enclosure must be 
constructed and maintained so that they have no sharp points that could potentially injure the birds.  
Correct by: 09/27/2024 
3.153(a)(1)(ix) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
A Red-Trailed Hawk Enclosure had many walls with exposed damaged plywood that was not able to be effectively 
cleaned and sanitized. Additionally, the woodpecker enclosure had rusty support beams. Enclosures must be constructed 
and maintained so that all surfaces in contact with the birds may be readily cleaned and/or sanitized in accordance with 
3.158 or be replaced when worn or soiled. 
Correct by: 09/26/2024

3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The facility did not have a documented environment enhancement plan to promote psychological well-being of their avian 
species as required by the Animal Welfare Act. The facility must develop, document and follow a species appropriate plan 
for environmental enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by 
the attending veterinarian, and at a minimum must address social grouping, environmental enrichment, special 
considerations, restraint, and exemptions to the plan regulation and be in accordance with currently accepted professional 
standards. 
Correct by: 09/26/2024 
3.158(a)(1) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The primary enclosure with a RedTailed Hawk was dirty with a buildup of wet excrement covering the walls. Insufficient 
cleaning can lead to disease hazards, insects, pest and odors. Excreta must be removed from within, under, and around 
the primary enclosure often enough to prevent excessive accumulation. 
Correct by: 09/26/2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Facility Representative.
